scenario:
Coca-Cola (KO) and PepsiCo (PEP) have both fallen by around 14% from their 52-week highs. PepsiCo's 2024 has been worse, down more than 10% year to date, while Coca-Cola is up by about 5%. However, PepsiCo's drop from its three-year high is around 22%, while Coca-Cola's is around 14%. 

PepsiCo's price-to-sales ratio is nearly 18% below its five-year average, while Coca-Cola's P/S ratio is only about 7% lower than its five-year average. PepsiCo's price-to-earnings ratio is about 14% below its five-year average, while Coca-Cola's P/E is roughly 2% below its average. 

PepsiCo yields 3.5% while Coca-Cola yields 3.1%. However, PepsiCo's yield is near its all-time high, while Coca-Cola's is roughly middle of the road for the stock over recent years. 

Both companies have increased their dividends annually for over 50 years, earning them spots among the Dividend Kings. Coca-Cola has grown its revenue at a slightly faster clip over the past few years, and its earnings have increased at a dramatically faster pace. 

PepsiCo sells beverages, snacks, and packaged food products, providing diversification, while Coca-Cola only sells beverages. If diversification is important, PepsiCo may be the better choice.
